trans-unit.source: Replaces discrete values from one column with numeric values based on another column
trans-unit.target: Replaces discrete values from one column with numeric values based on another column

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui> module to generate a probability score that can be used to represent a discrete value.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui> module to generate a probability score that can be used to represent a discrete value.

trans-unit.source: This can be useful for understanding the information value of the discrete values.
trans-unit.target: This can be useful for understanding the information value of the discrete values.

trans-unit.source: You select a column that contains the discrete (or categorical) value, and then select another column to use for reference.
trans-unit.target: You select a column that contains the discrete (or categorical) value, and then select another column to use for reference.

trans-unit.source: Depending on whether the second column is categorical or non-categorical, the module computes one of the following values:
trans-unit.target: Depending on whether the second column is categorical or non-categorical, the module computes one of the following values:

trans-unit.source: The <legacyBold>conditional probability</legacyBold> for the second column given the values in the first column.
trans-unit.target: The <legacyBold>conditional probability</legacyBold> for the second column given the values in the first column.

trans-unit.source: The <legacyBold>mean</legacyBold> and <legacyBold>standard deviation</legacyBold> for each group of values in the first column.
trans-unit.target: The <legacyBold>mean</legacyBold> and <legacyBold>standard deviation</legacyBold> for each group of values in the first column.

trans-unit.source: The module outputs both a transformed dataset, and a function that you can save as a transform and apply to other datasets.
trans-unit.target: The module outputs both a transformed dataset, and a function that you can save as a transform and apply to other datasets.

trans-unit.source: How to Configure Replace Discrete Values
trans-unit.target: How to Configure Replace Discrete Values

trans-unit.source: For the <ui>Discrete columns</ui> option, click <ui>Launch column selector</ui> to choose one or more columns that contain discrete (or categorical) values
trans-unit.target: For the <ui>Discrete columns</ui> option, click <ui>Launch column selector</ui> to choose one or more columns that contain discrete (or categorical) values

trans-unit.source: The discrete columns you select here must be categorical.
trans-unit.target: The discrete columns you select here must be categorical.

trans-unit.source: Use the <link xlink:href="370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Metadata Editor</link> module to mark the columns if you get an error.
trans-unit.target: Use the <link xlink:href="370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Metadata Editor</link> module to mark the columns if you get an error.

trans-unit.source: For the <ui>Replacement columns</ui> option, click <ui>Launch column selector</ui> to choose one or more columns that contain the values to use in computing a replacement score.
trans-unit.target: For the <ui>Replacement columns</ui> option, click <ui>Launch column selector</ui> to choose one or more columns that contain the values to use in computing a replacement score.

trans-unit.source: You must select an equal number of columns to the discrete columns in the previous step, and they cannot be the same columns.
trans-unit.target: You must select an equal number of columns to the discrete columns in the previous step, and they cannot be the same columns.

trans-unit.source: The module does allow you to select more than one pair of columns to analyze.
trans-unit.target: The module does allow you to select more than one pair of columns to analyze.

trans-unit.source: However, in practice, when you choose multiple columns, they are matched by an internal heuristic, not by order of selection.
trans-unit.target: However, in practice, when you choose multiple columns, they are matched by an internal heuristic, not by order of selection.

trans-unit.source: To ensure that you get the right replacement values, we recommend that you select a pair of columns each time and use separate instances of <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui> if analyzing multiple columns.
trans-unit.target: To ensure that you get the right replacement values, we recommend that you select a pair of columns each time and use separate instances of <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui> if analyzing multiple columns.

trans-unit.source: Depending on whether the second column is categorical or non-categorical, the module computes one of the following values:
trans-unit.target: Depending on whether the second column is categorical or non-categorical, the module computes one of the following values:

trans-unit.source: If the second column is a categorical value, it computes the <legacyBold>conditional probability</legacyBold> for the second column given the values in the first column.
trans-unit.target: If the second column is a categorical value, it computes the <legacyBold>conditional probability</legacyBold> for the second column given the values in the first column.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you choose <embeddedLabel>occupation</embeddedLabel> (from the Census dataset) as the discrete column and choose <embeddedLabel>gender</embeddedLabel> as the replacement column.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you choose <embeddedLabel>occupation</embeddedLabel> (from the Census dataset) as the discrete column and choose <embeddedLabel>gender</embeddedLabel> as the replacement column.

trans-unit.source: If the second column non-categorical values that can be converted to numbers (such as numeric or Boolean values <legacyBold>not</legacyBold> marked as categorical), it calculates the <legacyBold>mean</legacyBold> and <legacyBold>standard deviation</legacyBold> for each group of values in the first column.
trans-unit.target: If the second column non-categorical values that can be converted to numbers (such as numeric or Boolean values <legacyBold>not</legacyBold> marked as categorical), it calculates the <legacyBold>mean</legacyBold> and <legacyBold>standard deviation</legacyBold> for each group of values in the first column.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you select <embeddedLabel>occupation</embeddedLabel> as the <ui>Discrete column</ui> and the numeric column <embeddedLabel>hours-per-week</embeddedLabel> as the <ui>Replacement column</ui>, the new value columns would have these headings:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you select <embeddedLabel>occupation</embeddedLabel> as the <ui>Discrete column</ui> and the numeric column <embeddedLabel>hours-per-week</embeddedLabel> as the <ui>Replacement column</ui>, the new value columns would have these headings:

trans-unit.source: You cannot choose the statistical function to apply.
trans-unit.target: You cannot choose the statistical function to apply.

trans-unit.source: The module calculates the appropriate measure, based on the data type of the column selected for <ui>Replacement column</ui>.
trans-unit.target: The module calculates the appropriate measure, based on the data type of the column selected for <ui>Replacement column</ui>.

trans-unit.source: The module outputs a transformed dataset in which the columns you selected as the <ui>Replacement columns</ui> have been replaced with the computed scores.
trans-unit.target: The module outputs a transformed dataset in which the columns you selected as the <ui>Replacement columns</ui> have been replaced with the computed scores.

trans-unit.source: The headings of the new columns indicate the source columns and the operation.
trans-unit.target: The headings of the new columns indicate the source columns and the operation.

trans-unit.source: Use the Column Selector to choose columns to analyze.
trans-unit.target: Use the Column Selector to choose columns to analyze.

trans-unit.source: The columns must contain discrete values, and they must be already marked as categorical.
trans-unit.target: The columns must contain discrete values, and they must be already marked as categorical.

trans-unit.source: Choose columns to replace with scores.
trans-unit.target: Choose columns to replace with scores.

trans-unit.source: These columns are used to computes the scores, but only the scores are output.
trans-unit.target: These columns are used to computes the scores, but only the scores are output.

trans-unit.source: Although the original column values for the replacement columns are not included in the transformed dataset, the actual data columns in your dataset are not directly affected by the transformation; the new score columns are just added as metadata.
trans-unit.target: Although the original column values for the replacement columns are not included in the transformed dataset, the actual data columns in your dataset are not directly affected by the transformation; the new score columns are just added as metadata.

trans-unit.source: You can always get the column values by using add columns and connecting the source dataset..
trans-unit.target: You can always get the column values by using add columns and connecting the source dataset..

trans-unit.source: The sample experiments do not include any instances that are relevant to this module, but the usage of <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui> can be illustrated by some simple examples:
trans-unit.target: The sample experiments do not include any instances that are relevant to this module, but the usage of <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui> can be illustrated by some simple examples:

trans-unit.source: Replacing a Categorical Value with a Probability Score
trans-unit.target: Replacing a Categorical Value with a Probability Score

trans-unit.source: The following table contains a categorical column X, and a column Y with True/False values that are treated as categorical values.
trans-unit.target: The following table contains a categorical column X, and a column Y with True/False values that are treated as categorical values.

trans-unit.source: When you use <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui>, it calculates a conditional probability score as shown in the third column.
trans-unit.target: When you use <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui>, it calculates a conditional probability score as shown in the third column.

trans-unit.source: Replacement based on noncategorical column Y
trans-unit.target: Replacement based on noncategorical column Y

trans-unit.source: If the second column is numerical, <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui> calculates <math>Mean(Y|X)</math> and <math>Std-Dev(Y|X)</math> instead of the conditional probability score.
trans-unit.target: If the second column is numerical, <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui> calculates <math>Mean(Y|X)</math> and <math>Std-Dev(Y|X)</math> instead of the conditional probability score.

trans-unit.source: This example is based on the sample Auto Prices dataset.
trans-unit.target: This example is based on the sample Auto Prices dataset.

trans-unit.source: To simplify validation, a small subset of columns is projected and only the top 30 rows are extracted by using the Head option of <ui>Partition and Sample</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To simplify validation, a small subset of columns is projected and only the top 30 rows are extracted by using the Head option of <ui>Partition and Sample</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Then <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui> is used to compute the mean values and standard deviation for curb weight given the categorical column, <database>num-of-doors</database>.
trans-unit.target: Then <ui>Replace Discrete Values</ui> is used to compute the mean values and standard deviation for curb weight given the categorical column, <database>num-of-doors</database>.

trans-unit.source: You can verify the mean and standard deviation for each group of values by using the <languageKeyword>AVERAGEIF</languageKeyword> function in Excel.
trans-unit.target: You can verify the mean and standard deviation for each group of values by using the <languageKeyword>AVERAGEIF</languageKeyword> function in Excel.

trans-unit.source: This example demonstrates how missing values (nulls) propagate to the results.
trans-unit.target: This example demonstrates how missing values (nulls) propagate to the results.

trans-unit.source: If the discrete value column and the calculation lookup column contains any missing values, the missing values are propagated to the new column.
trans-unit.target: If the discrete value column and the calculation lookup column contains any missing values, the missing values are propagated to the new column.

trans-unit.source: If the discrete value column contains only missing values, the module cannot process the column and an error message appears.
trans-unit.target: If the discrete value column contains only missing values, the module cannot process the column and an error message appears.

trans-unit.source: You must ensure that any discrete columns you want to replace are categorical, or the module will return an error.
trans-unit.target: You must ensure that any discrete columns you want to replace are categorical, or the module will return an error.

trans-unit.source: You can do this by using <link xlink:href="370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Metadata Editor</link>.
trans-unit.target: You can do this by using <link xlink:href="370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Metadata Editor</link>.

trans-unit.source: If the second column contains Boolean values, the True-False values are processed as numeric with FALSE and TRUE equivalent to 0 and 1 respectively.
trans-unit.target: If the second column contains Boolean values, the True-False values are processed as numeric with FALSE and TRUE equivalent to 0 and 1 respectively.

trans-unit.source: The formula for the standard deviation column calculates the population standard deviation.
trans-unit.target: The formula for the standard deviation column calculates the population standard deviation.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, <math>N</math> is used in the denominator instead of <math>(N - 1)</math>.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, <math>N</math> is used in the denominator instead of <math>(N - 1)</math>.

trans-unit.source: If the second column contains noncategorical data (numeric or Boolean values), the module computes the mean and standard deviation of Y for the given value of X—that is, for each row in the dataset indexed by i:
trans-unit.target: If the second column contains noncategorical data (numeric or Boolean values), the module computes the mean and standard deviation of Y for the given value of X—that is, for each row in the dataset indexed by i:

trans-unit.source: If the second column contains categorical data or values that are neither numeric nor Boolean, the module computes the conditional probability of Y for the given value of X—that is, for each row in the dataset indexed by i.
trans-unit.target: If the second column contains categorical data or values that are neither numeric nor Boolean, the module computes the conditional probability of Y for the given value of X—that is, for each row in the dataset indexed by i.

trans-unit.source: Any Boolean values in the second column are processed as numeric data with FALSE and TRUE equivalent to 0 and 1 respectively.
trans-unit.target: Any Boolean values in the second column are processed as numeric data with FALSE and TRUE equivalent to 0 and 1 respectively.

trans-unit.source: If there is a class in the discrete column, such that a row with a missing value is present in the second column, the sum of conditional probabilities within the class is less than one.
trans-unit.target: If there is a class in the discrete column, such that a row with a missing value is present in the second column, the sum of conditional probabilities within the class is less than one.

trans-unit.source: Selects the columns that contain discrete values
trans-unit.target: Selects the columns that contain discrete values

trans-unit.source: Selects the columns that contain the data to use in place of the discrete values
trans-unit.target: Selects the columns that contain the data to use in place of the discrete values

trans-unit.source: Definition of the transform function, which can be applied to other datasets
trans-unit.target: Definition of the transform function, which can be applied to other datasets

trans-unit.source: For a complete list of error messages, see <link xlink:href="60822377-da7a-40b8-aec7-d185d1509344" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Error Codes</link>.
trans-unit.target: For a complete list of error messages, see <link xlink:href="60822377-da7a-40b8-aec7-d185d1509344" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Error Codes</link>.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if one or more specified columns of the data set couldn't be found.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if one or more specified columns of the data set couldn't be found.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if one or more of inputs are null or empty.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if one or more of inputs are null or empty.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if the number of columns in some of the datasets passed to the module is too small.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if the number of columns in some of the datasets passed to the module is too small.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if the number of rows in some of the datasets passed to the module is too small.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if the number of rows in some of the datasets passed to the module is too small.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if one or more specified columns have a type that is unsupported by the current module.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if one or more specified columns have a type that is unsupported by the current module.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs when columns with the same name are not allowed.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs when columns with the same name are not allowed.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if the number of selected columns in the input dataset does not equal the expected number.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if the number of selected columns in the input dataset does not equal the expected number.
